7610263794ea.title: As much fun as this couple weeks has been, it’s mostly made me sad about the whole Kevin Durant…

paragraphs.text: As much fun as this couple weeks has been, it’s mostly made me sad about the whole Kevin Durant thing. I understood his decision and probably would’ve made the same one, but I knew we were losing this version of Curry and I can’t properly enjoy it now because we’re about to lose it again.
paragraphs.name: dde7

paragraphs.text: As others have noted, at this point Curry’s basically a victim of his own impossible to meet peak standards. As good as he’s has played this year, he was never going to repeat what he did last season (especially with KD on the team).

f4ac3452b401.title: I’m happy to see that at least someone is still looking at the season as a whole rather than just…

paragraphs.text: I’m happy to see that at least someone is still looking at the season as a whole rather than just focusing on the middle part of the season. The four current front runners are great, but they all have flaws and their teams performance has also been up and down. Curry has shown that any time he is on the court he makes his team more dangerous. That is…
paragraphs.name: 93a3

7973075212bc.bio: Top Medium writer in sports, TV, humor, NFL, NBA. Words at Cauldron, 16 Wins Ring, Sports Pickle, Bleacher Report, Hoop NBA, and others @wheatonbrando
7973075212bc.name: Brandon Anderson

paragraphs.text: Sometimes we make up our mind about what kind of season an NBA player or team is having, and we just stick to it, no matter what happens late in the campaign. Take Steph Curry, for example. The two-time defending MVP spent the year rebounding from an embarrassing Finals collapse, adjusting to the arrival of a 6-foot-9 Reaper in his offense, and putting up one of the worst shooting nights ever by the very stroke that famed him (and a low-pressure system that threw off his shot). This time last year, he was being coronated as one of the game’s all-time greats. Now, he finds himself removed from the MVP conversation, left out as we debate the merits of a seemingly exclusive club of four — James Harden, Russell Westbrook, Kawhi Leonard, LeBron James.
paragraphs.name: a796

paragraphs.text: Thankfully, Steph Curry did not get the message about our fixed story lines. And as Exhibits A through K, he’d like to present this little 11-game winning streak he’s led the Warriors on.

Sometimes we make up our mind about what kind of season an NBA player or team is having, and we just stick to it, no matter what happens late in the campaign. Take Steph Curry, for example. The two-time defending MVP spent the year rebounding from an embarrassing Finals collapse, adjusting to the arrival of a 6-foot-9 Reaper in his offense, and putting up one of the worst shooting nights ever by the very stroke that famed him (and a low-pressure system that threw off his shot). This time last year, he was being coronated as one of the game’s all-time greats. Now, he finds himself removed from the MVP conversation, left out as we debate the merits of a seemingly exclusive club of four — James Harden, Russell Westbrook, Kawhi Leonard, LeBron James.
paragraphs.name: a796
